I am currently at (3, 2), and my goal is (3, 3). The direct path is one step right to (3, 3), which is a G-colored tile. To move onto (3, 3), I need to pay 1 green chip. I currently have 2 green chips in my inventory, so I can afford this move. Moving directly to (3, 3) will allow me to reach my goal immediately, earning me 20 points plus 5 points for each remaining chip. After this move, I will have 1 green chip left (since I use 1), and 10 blue chips. That gives me a total score of 20 + (5 * 1) + (5 * 10) = 20 + 5 + 50 = 75 points. This is a guaranteed high score if I complete the move now. 

The other player is already at (3, 2), and their goal is also (3, 3). However, I note that they currently have no blue chips, only 2 green and 8 red chips. They cannot move to (3, 3) without paying 1 green chip, which they have — so they could potentially claim the goal themselves on their next turn. But according to our contract, if I reach my goal, I receive 0 points from them, but if they reach their goal, I must give them 20 points. Therefore, by reaching (3, 3) now, I prevent them from claiming the goal and avoid having to give away 20 points. This decision is strictly beneficial: I gain 75 points and avoid losing 20. 

No trade is needed — I have enough green chips to complete the move. There is no benefit in delaying or trading, as the shortest path is free of any chip shortages and leads to immediate scoring. Delaying would risk letting the other player move first and claim the goal, which would cost me 20 points.
